summary: human hepatoma cell lines have been evaluated for hepatitis C virus (HCV) infection in vitro. so far only Huh7 cells have been found to be highly permissive for infectious HCV. a panel of hepatic and non-hepatic cell lines assessed their ability to support HCV infection. between 130 and 170 million individuals are chronically infected with hepatitis C virus (HCV), a positive-strand RNA virus that infects the liver. 80% of patients fail to clear the virus resulting in a chronic infection associated with the development of significant liver disease. despite this obvious public health burden, there is no vaccine to prevent infection. to identify other cell lines suitable for HCV infection studies, we assembled a panel of hepatic and non-hepatic cell lines and assessed their permissiveness for HCVcc infection. a comprehensive analysis of the permissiveness of human hepatic and non-hepatic cell lines for HCVcc infection has yet to be reported. cells were infected with pseudotyped lentiviruses encoding a luciferase reporter and bearing the glycoproteins E1 and E2 of HCV genotype 2a (JFHpp), HCV E1 and E2 of genotype 1a (H77pp) or the VSV G glycoprotein (VSVGpp). at 72 h post infection, pseudoparticle entry was assessed by luciferase activity as previously described. indicated cell lines were infected with HCVcc at an MOI of 2.0 FFU/cell. intracellular RNA was collected 72 h p.i. and HCV RNA is displayed as HCV RNA copies/g total cellular RNA. Caco-2 cells have previously been reported to support suboptimal HCVcc infection [35]. the low levels of HCV RNA (p value > 0.05) measured in these infected cultures are likely due to receptor-bound HCV similar to that of the non-permissive parental HepG2 cell line. hepatoma-derived hepatoma-derived cells lines share similar hepatocytes-like characteristics with Huh7 cells. these lines also share permissiveness for both HCVpp and HCVccc infection albeit to different degrees. expression of HCV entry factors on hepatoma cells was determined by flow cytometric analysis or IF. total RNA was extracted from Huh7, PLC, Hep3B and HepG2-CD81 cells. mRNA copies were determined by RTqPCR using standard curves. we transiently transfected PLC, Hep3B and HepG2-CD81 cells with vectors expressing the four known human HCV receptors. expression of HCV entry factors in trans individually (Figure 3) or in combination (data not shown) did not enhance HCVpp or HCVcc (Figure 3D-F) infectivity of PLC, Hep3B or HepG2-CD81 cells. 65% less luciferase activity generated when cells were ino /g total cellular RNA SD for triplicate samples determined 72 h p.i. both PLC and Hep3B cells support equivalent levels of HCV RNA replication. reduced permissiveness for HCVcc infection compared to Huh7 cells may be due to defects in HCV RNA replication.
